710117f-a.title: Manhattan: 8th Avenue - 23rd Street
710117f-a.text:
Grand Opera House (originally known as Pike's Opera House),
Eighth Avenue at N. W. corner of 23rd Street.
In the 1870's, Jay Gould and Colonel James Fisk had execut-
ive offices of the Erie Railroad here.
This theatre has one of the largest stages in New York.
June 1925.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
The Opera House will be dmmolished as per ''The Ney York Herald
Tribune,''of July 18, 1937, which also includes a hhictorical resume,
pertinent to this structure.

710120f-c.text:
(1)
Eighth Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 23rd Streeh. Also shown,
is West 23rd Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Eighth Ave. Cor-
ner building is the Grand Opera House, by this time presenting vaadeville
and ''movies''.
June 27, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing a front view of the Grand Cpera House.
December 26, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(3)
The same, showing a closer view. The 4 story building adjoining the
Opera House is No. 273 Eighth Ave. Note the Cornish Arma Hotel.
December 26, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

710119f-a.title: Manhattan: 8th Avenue - 23rd Street (West)
710119f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue (right), at the N.W. corner of West 23rd
Street (left), showing the Grand Opera House. This house
was built and opened by Samuel N. Pike as Pike's Opera
Souse, January 9, 1868. James Fisk and Jay Could purchased
the house in March 1869 and gave it the present name.
1670s
4
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street, N.Y.C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICHTS UNENOwN

710122f-b.title: Manhattan: 8th Avenue - 23rd Street (West)
710122f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, north from '. 23rd Street, showing mainly build-
ings on the west side of same. At the left is the Grand Opera House,
built by Samuel N. Pike as Pike's Opera House and opened January 9,
1868 with a performance of ''Il Trovatore.'' James Fisk and Jay Gould
purchased it in March 1869. The latter wibhdrew and the theatre be-
came identified with Fisk. At his death, his formerr oartner took over.
View 1: January 22, 1929
View 2: June 3, 1930
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODICTIONS
